title: Setting Up
description: Welcome to the first chapter of The Legend of Python! Python is a beginner-friendly programming language created by Guido van Rossum in the early 1990s. It is widely used in many fields, including Artificial Intelligence, Web Development, Data Analysis, and Machine Learning. Install Python and set up your coding environment to run Python scripts.
task: Print a welcome message to the terminal using the print() function.
hints: Make sure your code runs without errors.

title: Hello World
description: Printing output is one of the first skills in programming. In Python, the print() function is used to display text or information in the terminal so you can see what your program is doing.
hints: Put your message inside the parentheses.

title: Pattern
description: Programs can print text across multiple lines to create patterns and shapes. By using the print() function with special characters, you can control how output appears line by line in the terminal.

title: Initials
description: Programs often need to display information line by line. By using multiple print() statements, you can control exactly how text appears in the terminal. This exercise helps you practice printing output on separate lines.
task: Print your initials, each on a new line.
hints: Each initial on a new line.

title: Variables
description: Store information using variables.Variables are containers for storing data values. In Python, no command for declaring a variable is needed. A variable is formed when you first assign a value to it.
task: Create a variable to store your hero's name and print it.

title: Strings
description: Strings are used to store and work with text in Python. You can combine multiple strings together using the + operator to create longer messages. This lesson introduces basic string concatenation and printing text to the terminal.
task: Create a string variable with a greeting and print it with ' World' appended.

title: Numbers
description: Variables of numeric types are created when you assign a value to them. Use numeric values and arithmetic operations in Python.
task: Create two numeric variables, add them, and print the result.

title: Booleans
description: Booleans represent logical values in Python and can only be either True or False. They are commonly used to describe conditions or states, such as whether something is on or off, or yes or no. This lesson introduces how to create and print boolean values.
task: Create a boolean variable indicating if you are a student and print it.

title: If Statements
description: If statements allow a program to make decisions based on conditions. When a condition evaluates to True, the code inside the if block runs. This helps control the flow of a program so it can respond differently depending on the data.
task: Create an if statement that checks if age is 18 or older and prints 'Adult' if true.
hints: Indent the code inside if block.

title: Else & Elif
description: Sometimes a program needs to check more than one condition. The elif and else keywords allow you to create a chain of conditions so different code runs depending on which condition is true. This lesson teaches how to handle multiple possible outcomes using if, elif, and else.
task: Create an if-elif-else statement to categorize age into 'Adult', 'Teen', or 'Child'.

title: Comparison
description: Comparison operators are used to compare two values in Python. These operators check relationships such as greater than, less than, or equal to, and they return a Boolean value of True or False. Comparisons are commonly used in decision-making and conditional statements.
task: Compare two numbers and print whether the first is greater than the second.

title: Logical Operators
description: Logical operators allow you to combine multiple Boolean conditions into a single expression. Using and, or, and not, you can check more complex logic and make decisions based on more than one condition at the same time.
task: Use logical operators to evaluate two boolean variables and print the result.
lessonExample:
a = True
b = False
print(a and b)

title: For Loops
description: For loops are used to repeat a block of code a specific number of times. They are commonly used when you know in advance how many times an action should run, such as iterating through a range of numbers.
task: Use a for loop to print numbers from 0 to 2.
hints: Use range() to define loop count.
Indent the code inside the loop.

title: While Loops
description: While loops repeat a block of code as long as a condition remains True. They are useful when you do not know in advance how many times the loop should run and want the loop to stop based on a condition.
task: Use a while loop to print numbers from 0 to 2.

title: Range Function
description: The range() function is used to generate a sequence of numbers, often in combination with for loops. It allows you to control where a loop starts and stops, making it easy to repeat actions a specific number of times.
task: Use range() to print numbers from 1 to 4.
hints: Use start and end values in range().

title: Nested Loops
description: Nested loops occur when one loop runs inside another loop. The inner loop completes all of its iterations for each iteration of the outer loop. Nested loops are useful for working with combinations, grids, and patterns.
task: Use nested loops to print all pairs of numbers from 0 to 1.
hints: Use a loop inside another loop.

title: Python Exam
description: Test your Python knowledge with exercises covering all modules.
task: Create a function that takes two numbers as input, adds them together, and prints the result.
hints: Use variables, functions, loops, and conditionals.
